channel.title: Things on Alex Dunn has no idea what he‚Äôs doing
channel.description: Recent content in Things on Alex Dunn has no idea what he‚Äôs doing

item.title: WordPreSSL
item.description: This is an Ansible playbook for provisioning a CentOS server with an SSL-enabled WordPress installation. The original motivation was to be able to quickly set up websites for friends and associates in the spirit of Brianna Laugher‚Äôs ‚ÄúPlaying Sysadmin for my Activist Mates‚Äù. Feedback, testing, and pull requests are all very welcome.

item.title: company-emoji.el
item.description:
If you use Emacs, you‚Äôre a big ‚Äôol nerd. But you can still pretend to be cool by using emoji like the teens and moms do. All it takes is company-mode and company-emoji.el. Install them both (using MELPA or Homebrew or manually), then add something like this to your emacs.el:

(require 'company-emoji)
(add-to-list 'company-backends 'company-emoji)

Then Büí•üí•M.

item.title: libgen.js
item.description:
libgen is a Node.js wrapper for the Library Genesis API, with search added on top of it. Install it in the root folder of your project with npm install libgen, then require it where it’s needed:

var libgen = require('libgen');

Your application then has access to search, random texts, and other methods.

item.title: The Good Trolle
item.description:
The Good Trolle is a new Twitter citizen who serves two complementary roles:

  1. It notifies its battle-ready followers of racists, sexists, homophobes, transphobes, and ableists in need of a good drubbing, and it does this by:

  2. allowing anyone overwhelmed by said jerks to tweet at @good_trolle and offload the abuse onto people with the time and energy to shoulder the burden.

item.title: Jerry Fodor's Wittgenstein parody
item.description: Sometime in the 60s Michael Frayn wrote a goofy parody of Ludwig Wittgenstein’s Philosophical Investigations, and around 1970 Jerry Fodor wrote some “further addenda.” Fodor’s parody isn’t really as good, but it still deserves to be better preserved than it is at present, so I transcribed it here.

item.title: Exists.js
item.description: If you’re a scumbag analytic philosopher like me then this might actually come in handy, like when your “friend” suggests that chairs are ontologically innocent.

item.title: Reading.js
item.description:
Reading.js is a crummy bit of CSS and JavaScript that’s supposed to make it easier to read long documents online. (Like this one!)

Include two lines in the <head> of a plain HTML file—the kind produced by pandoc or by most Markdown-to-HTML converters—and gain nifty features like keyboard shortcuts, section folding, and color scheme switching:

<link rel="stylesheet" href="http://baruffio.com/reading.js/stylesheets/reading.css" />
<script type="text/javascript" src="http://baruffio.com/reading.js/scripts/reading.min.js"></script>

item.title: Fountain CLM
item.description:
Codeless Language Modules (CLMs) are plugins for TextWrangler and BBEdit that add syntax highlighting, code folding, and other capabilities for languages not natively supported by these programs.

Fountain is a plain-text syntax for writing screenplays. (The Fountain syntax is similar to that of Markdown, a general-purpose syntax.) Fountain files are designed to be very readable, but they can be easily converted to other formats (like PDF and FDX) using Fountain-compatible applications.
